title: Spain gets another election as coalition talks fail
text:
Acting Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez | Philippe Marcou/AFP via Getty Images Spain gets another election as coalition talks fail Pedro Sánchez and his rivals blame each other for failure to make progress.

MADRID — Spaniards will go to the ballot box on November 10 — for the fourth national election in as many years.

Acting Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez, whose Socialists won the last election in April but fell short of a majority, was unable to secure parliamentary backing to form a government.

“The country is forced to hold a repeat election,” Sánchez told reporters late Tuesday, after King Felipe VI met with party leaders.

“I’ve tried everything, but it was impossible,” Sánchez added, blaming his rivals for the deadlock and asking Spaniards to “speak more clearly” when they vote again, by increasing the Socialists’ majority.

Sánchez targeted in particular far-left Podemos leader Pablo Iglesias, whom he described as the only leader on the left in Europe who has derailed “four times” the possibility of a progressive government.

The parliament will now automatically be dissolved and the new ballot officially called on Monday.

The decision to hold a new election came after a failed attempt to have Sánchez sworn in as prime minister in July, the failure to make progress in talks between the Socialists and Podemos — which stalled over whether the latter should get Cabinet positions, something the Socialists refused — and a few last-minute surprises.

On Monday, the leader of the center-right Ciudadanos party, Albert Rivera, who had long refused to cooperate with the Socialists, made a surprise offer to back Sánchez’s investiture, but under certain conditions, which Rivera said the Socialists did not meet. Rivals accused Rivera of trying to avoid being blamed for a fresh election being called.

Así ha propuesto Rivera al PP abstenerse junto a Cs en la investidura de Sánchez, si este asume compromisos sobre Navarra, Cataluña y la economía española https://t.co/zAauVGEMiY pic.twitter.com/VWm1EXVmtw — Europa Press (@europapress) September 16, 2019

“If Sánchez rectifies, there’s still time to get the country going,” Rivera said in Congress on Tuesday, arguing that the Socialist leader had to choose between a deal with Podemos, a new election and what he dubbed a statesman’s “solution.”

“Sánchez wanted a new election from the beginning,” Popular Party leader Pablo Casado told reporters on Tuesday, saying he hoped citizens will punish that attitude at the ballot box.

Podemos’ Iglesias accused Sánchez of preferring an agreement on his right, with Rivera, rather than on his left.

Opinion polls predict the Socialists will do better than the 29 percent they picked up in April, while Podemos, Ciudadanos and the far-right Vox will lose ground. The Popular Party is forecast to make gains at the expense of Vox and Ciudadanos.
